intro: Oxydium, commonly known as the common watermeal, is a small aquatic plant belonging to the family Zygnemataceae. It is a free-floating plant that lacks true roots, stems, and leaves, instead having a simple, branched structure. Oxydium thrives in still or slow-moving freshwater environments, often forming dense mats on the surface of ponds and lakes. Its reproductive structures, called zoospores, are released into the water and can germinate under favorable conditions. This plant plays a role in aquatic ecosystems by providing habitat for small organisms and contributing to nutrient cycling.
